snippet.textDisplay: I believe with what some people said as "overreacting" was meant due to some people hoarding all the groceries in a short amount of time leaving many other people without anything else to buy for a few days. snippet.textDisplay:
At 2:36 they use the same formula that explains compound interest. Watch this video to see what I'm talking about. https://youtu.be/Uka5owZdFDI
Just replace pennies with people infected.
If the CDC and this video I shared is right billions have already gotten covid 19. Why on this video did they go for 60 days? Do that math! There are not even that many people alive. If they claim one will infect two, two, four and so on and so on for 60 days that means we will all get infected. Most likely we have already been infected. If that is the rate they claim it will spread. This is because we don't show symptoms till days after we have contracted and then spread the virus. So the good and bad news. Bad news everyone will get covid 19, according to these numbers probably already has it. Ask yourself have you been sick in the last 3 months? Good news you have probably already gotten it and if you are reading this your probably fine. This does raise a question if everyone will get the virus and very few get tested and diagnosed that means the death rate is far lower than we see talked about thus the statistics are way off and we are making a big deal out of something that statistically is not dangerous to most people. If you are old with other health conditions yes this could be a problem. On that same note we will all get old and have many underlying health conditions and we will all die of something. My last question why have we shut everything down? This doesn't make sense. Something strange is going on and it's not the virus. The flu is normal this situation is not.

snippet.textDisplay:
Guys, remember: The CDC is now admitting that CoVid-19 has been going around for at least 2 months in the United States of America and worldwide now.
These 'blips' in the number of people being infected by CoVid-19-SARS variant? Most likely people who have been trying to fight off this illness for weeks or months and the majority of them are people with severe health issues, untreated health issues, or elderly over 65 years of age.
Truth in the real world: CoVid-19 is not a pandemic. At most, it is a seasonal illness ala H1N1 that we have to keep an eye on but that the bulk of the populace will have a minor illness to moderate illness from (need a few days of bed rest) and they will be fine.
By bulk, I mean 95%+.... and that is assuming that a lot of people have not already had this illness at this point considering again: Circulating for 2 months.

snippet.textDisplay:
FYI there is no known body of water capable of holding that many Lilly pads.

Assume each pad is 6"X6", So that 4 pads covers one sq ft. Of area. 2^59~ 5.7x10^17, covering ~1.44x10^17 sq ft of area. Converted to sq. Miles this is ~5 billion square miles. The Pacific ocean covers ~62 million sq miles. Thus, in order to contain all the Lilly pads (with no overlapping) our "pond" would need to be approximately 80 TIMES BIGGER THAN THE PACIFIC OCEAN.
snippet.textOriginal:
FYI there is no known body of water capable of holding that many Lilly pads.

The Pacific ocean covers ~62 million sq miles. Thus, in order to contain all the Lilly pads (with no overlapping) our "pond" would need to be approximately 80 TIMES BIGGER THAN THE PACIFIC OCEAN.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is one of the best videos on the matter, thanks for taking the time to put it together. But as I was watching it, it occurred to me we can't talk about turning from exponential to sigmoid unless at least one of the following conditions are met:
1. a cure is found
2. a vaccine is developed
3. immunity of recovered patients is confirmed
4. the whole population is dead
5. we find a way to isolate ourselves (all 7.5 billion of us) at the same time long enough for the virus to die out

Did I miss anything?
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Can the U.S. flatten the curve,...
No.
Italy went into complete lockdown on 3/9. On 3/20 their daily new cases and daily new deaths was still accelerating. The U.S., due to malignant and ignorant "leadership", has barely begun the total lockdown necessary. The U.S. cannot avoid the bad spike now.

The Governor of California, ONE OF THE FIRST TO LOCKDOWN, predicted 25 MILLION cases in CA in 8 weeks. Italy, with a better healthcare system than the U.S., collapsed with 40,000 cases. With a 15% hospitalization rate, CA would need 4 million hospital beds. IF the governor's projections are 1/1000th true, people needing hospitals will die at home.

The rest of the U.S., doing far less than CA, will follow because their populations are building the catastrophe now, like a tsunami out to sea, low and wide, before it breaks on the shore.

This foxy virus has some skills that is different from fluenza, covid19 can transmit during incubation period (no symptom period), this average incubation period is 14 days, longest can be 24 or longer. Of course it can also transmit during patient's mild condition.
One virus carrier can transmit the virus to many people, even a dozen, depending on how he exposes himself to the surroundings.
It can also transmit via aerosol.. please take extra caution.

snippet.textDisplay:
I was a bit late to the game but around the 20th February I could see what was happening in other countries.
I then stocked up on food that would keep as well as toilet paper and hand soap (I saw the toilet roll panic too), I also ordered a litre of hand sanitizer from the web. One week later that hand sanitizer was retailing for 5 times the amount I paid for it.
I live on my own and gently suggested to my family that they consider doing the same so that they could avoid the panic buying 'if' it happened.
One of my family members told me that I was nuts while another family member politely thanked me.
Neither of them acted on what I suggested.
One month later and I went to my local supermarket at 6:15 am this morning to get some fresh vegetables and the supermarket was as busy as it usually is at 11am on a normal Saturday.
I asked someone coming out if there were vegetables and they said there were - they volunteered that there was no toilet paper and offered me so from their bag - I thanked them, explaining that I had a supply at home and said "stay well".
People are amazing!

Mate, early on? We are already extremely late to take measures..... every measure now is already late, but hey.... better late than never.


Since the start of Feb I've been calling for OMS to call it epidemy, for my country to close borders with Italy, etc... only when it was already late some measures were taken... Even my boss told me on Friday that staying at home wouldn't matter since after 14 days we would return and be infected anyway.... on Sunday night he sent me a message saying the company was closing down for the near future... and that was because the government had issued a reduction of the quarantine days from 10 to just 5!!!! Before deciding to call it a national emergency and locking the entire country.... this is just a BS, the Governments aren't doing enough

snippet.textDisplay:
This is more total BS. The .gov wants 60% of the population to get infected to create "herd Immunity", which is actually needed. But this virus pales in compare to most regular flus. Let's take a look at last years flu numbers, and please, remember to keep the perspective of infected and recovered vs. deaths. "In total, the CDC estimates that up to 42.9 million people got sick during the 2018-2019 flu season, 647,000 people were hospitalized and 61,200 died. That's fairly on par with a typical season."


61K died last year because of the normal, run of the mill flu in the US. So far, worldwide, only 11K people have died from Covid 19. In the US, 275 deaths. So in REALITY, you only have something to fear if you have a respiratory precondition or you're old AF.

snippet.textDisplay: Please tell us, what is the R0 factor for corona? You cannot use a term like "exponential" and use the lily pond example of 60 days without knowing at what rate this illness spreads, in other words, what is it's contagious factor in lay terms.  The flu has an average R0 of 1.2. For every 1 person with the flu, 1.2 people will be infected. This is a fairly low contagious illness. The measles on the other hand has a factor of R18, so for every one person with the measles, 18 people will get infected. That is HIGHLY contagious. Now the latest information on corona is that it has a factor of R1.4, ever so slightly higher than the flu. The corona R0 factor may mean the curve will be flat without shutting down the global economy. In Italy, the number of reported cases today, about 47,000, represents less than 1% of the population, 0.07% to be nearly accurate. The number of deaths so far, (and even one death is too many) is .0067%. The virus first appeared in Washington on January 21, and this is March 20th, a full 2 months or 60 days. It has not "exponentially" spreading. 30,000 people have died in the US from the flu between Nov 2019 and February 2020. Read, reason, study and decipher.
snippet.textOriginal: Please tell us, what is the R0 factor for corona? You cannot use a term like "exponential" and use the lily pond example of 60 days without knowing at what rate this illness spreads, in other words, what is it's contagious factor in lay terms.  The flu has an average R0 of 1.2. For every 1 person with the flu, 1.2 people will be infected. This is a fairly low contagious illness. The measles on the other hand has a factor of R18, so for every one person with the measles, 18 people will get infected. That is HIGHLY contagious. Now the latest information on corona is that it has a factor of R1.4, ever so slightly higher than the flu. The corona R0 factor may mean the curve will be flat without shutting down the global economy. In Italy, the number of reported cases today, about 47,000, represents less than 1% of the population, 0.07% to be nearly accurate. The number of deaths so far, (and even one death is too many) is .0067%. The virus first appeared in Washington on January 21, and this is March 20th, a full 2 months or 60 days. It has not "exponentially" spreading. 30,000 people have died in the US from the flu between Nov 2019 and February 2020. Read, reason, study and decipher.

snippet.textDisplay:
I’ve been reading about flattening the curve all week but at the beginning of the week I had a hard time making sense of the predictions. China has 1.4 billion people but had only 80,000 cases at the time.
My son and I both have low immunity. Both my son and my daughter have hf autism and serious mood disorders. My wife and I joke (half seriously) it takes 60 hours of work each day between the two of us. If I croaked, my wife and kids would be left in an impossible situation. My dad texted me on Monday night, “Stock up, go to the farm, lock the gate and stay there for at least three weeks. Go now!” He’s not known for overreacting but I had to ask if he was serious. He was. Early April is going to be the worst time to be infected. I hope we can all be smart and in the end this will all unite us a bit. Not just the US but the whole world.
snippet.textOriginal:
I’ve been reading about flattening the curve all week but at the beginning of the week I had a hard time making sense of the predictions.  China has 1.4 billion people but had only 80,000 cases at the time.  
My son and I both have low immunity.  Both my son and my daughter have hf autism and serious mood disorders.  My wife and I joke (half seriously) it takes 60 hours of work each day between the two of us.  If I croaked, my wife and kids would be left in an impossible situation.  My dad texted me on Monday night, “Stock up, go to the farm, lock the gate and stay there for at least three weeks. Go now!”  He’s not known for overreacting but I had to ask if he was serious.  He was.  Early April is going to be the worst time to be infected.  I hope we can all be smart and in the end this will all unite us a bit.  Not just the US but the whole world.

snippet.textDisplay: I have a numbers question: to calculate the current mortality rate of Covid-19, should I only be looking at cases that are inactive (recovered/died)? Since the active cases haven’t resolved yet, is it accurate to include them in a mortality rate? There’s like a 7% difference between those numbers. I know rates will continue to change as we learn more, and depending on each county’s response, but I just want to keep track of the data and numbers. It helps keep me calm for some reason. I guess it’s Iike keeping an eye on my enemy.
snippet.textOriginal: I have a numbers question: to calculate the current mortality rate of Covid-19, should I only be looking at cases that are inactive (recovered/died)? I know rates will continue to change as we learn more, and depending on each county’s response, but I just want to keep track of the data and numbers. It helps keep me calm for some reason. I guess it’s Iike keeping an eye on my enemy.

snippet.textDisplay: What we are doing, shutting down the entire world economy, is an untested experiment. Putting up conceptual graphs does not make it science. I get the concept, that all we have to do is isolate everyone and the disease dies off. But the reality is, we can't isolate everyone, we can't even isolate most people. We all still have to live and many industries and businesses are simply vital to existence. If you look at the infection rates in the US, they look exactly like Italy did, just delayed a bit. Infections are growing with the same exponent. We are destroying our entire economy based on an unproven theory, and the early evidence is that it is not accomplishing anything. Hospitals are still going to be overwhelmed by around June 1...same prediction as before all these lock downs.
snippet.textOriginal: What we are doing, shutting down the entire world economy, is an untested experiment.  Putting up conceptual graphs does not make it science.  I get the concept, that all we have to do is isolate everyone and the disease dies off.  But the reality is, we *can't* isolate everyone, we can't even isolate most people.  We all still have to live and many industries and businesses are simply vital to existence.  If you look at the infection rates in the US, they look exactly like Italy did, just delayed a bit.  Infections are growing with the same exponent.  We are destroying our entire economy based on an unproven theory, and the early evidence is that it is not accomplishing anything.  Hospitals are still going to be overwhelmed by around June 1...same prediction as before all these lock downs.

snippet.textDisplay:
Short Answer: No (unless your are China)
History is repeating it self, from Justinian Plague to Spanish Flu to Corona Virus Plague, you can see people are keep making mistakes for not taking austerity measures until it was too late.
“The only lesson that human beings learn from history is that human beings have not learned any lessons from history.” by Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel
